_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan
Conectiv Bethlehem, LLC
Bethlehem, Pennsylvania

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 

Conectiv Bethlehem, LLC (Conectiv) is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for employees and contractors, the public, and the environment. The purpose of this Risk Management Program is to prepare for emergencies relating to the delivery, use and storage of anhydrous ammonia. 

The Bethlehem Plant stores and uses anhydrous ammonia in Selective Catalytic Reduction processes above the regulatory threshold amount (10,000 lbs) requiring the development of a Risk Management Plan (RMP) under U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) rules (Title 40 Code of Federal Regulations part 68). This document is used in conjunction with the Conectiv Process Safety Management (PSM) program. The purpose of this RMP is to provide the public with a description of the risk management program at Conectiv. 

Built on approximately 56 acres in Northampton County, Pennsylvania the Conectiv Bethlehem Plant utilizes anhydrous ammonia, CAS #7664-41-7, in its Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) process. SCR is a means of converting nitrogen oxides, also referred to as NOx, with the aid of a catalyst into diatomic nitrogen (N2) and water. A gaseous reductant, anhydrous ammonia, is added to a stream of flue or exhaust gases and is absorbed into a catalyst. At the Conectiv facility the anhydrous ammonia is received via tank truck delivery and is transferred into one of the two storage vessels on the southeast side of each power block. The facility has two 12,000 gallon storage tanks for anhydrous ammonia.  Engineering and administrative controls allow the tanks to be filled up to 85% of capacity.  The total amount of anhydrous ammonia on-site at any given time will not exceed 24,000 gallons.

Conectiv Bethlehem employees are trained to respond to releases of anhydrous ammonia of less than 300 ppm as measured by area monitors.  All release responses above 300 ppm will be conducted by local emergenc

y services. Conectiv will work closely with the local fire department and with the Northampton County local emergency planning committee (LEPC) to ensure injuries and/or environmental damage will be minimized if a release should occur. The facility employees have been trained on the use of personal protective equipment (PPE) and maintenance procedures to provide continued safe operation of the system.

To prevent an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia, the Conectiv Bethlehem Plant uses ongoing employee/contractor training, standard operating procedures, pre-startup safety reviews, management of change procedures, hot work permitting, emergency response drills and auditing programs as main components of its release prevention program.  The facility also has a preventative maintenance program; a pipe and valve labeling program; and an inspection program applicable to the regulated process. 

There have been no known accidental anhydrous ammonia releases from the system resulting in either an on-site or off-site consequence at the Bethlehem, Pennsylvania site.  

The Risk Management Program at Conectiv consists of three elements:

1.A hazard assessment to understand the potential offsite consequences of hypothetical accidental releases and a history of accidents that have occurred during the previous five years associated with the use of substances regulated by the RMP rule (regulated substances)
2.A prevention program to maintain and safely operate the process containing more than the threshold quantity of a regulated substance (covered processes) ? see topic 4.
3.An emergency response system to respond to accidental releases of regulated substances from covered processes ? see topic 6.

Conectiv also has a comprehensive safety program in place establishing various levels of safeguards against the accidental release of hazardous substances, injuries and property damage. Conectiv limits the use of hazardous substances by conducting feasibility studies of less hazar

dous alternatives.  Part of Conectiv?s RMP compliance philosophy is the continual reduction of the use of hazardous substances. When a hazardous substance is used, Conectiv considers the potential for the substance to adversely affect Conectiv employees and contractors, the public, and the environment and takes steps to prevent any such effects.  Equipment is designed, built, operated, and maintained to minimize the likelihood of an accidental release.  Government and industry standards are adhered to in the design, construction, operation and maintenance of the equipment.

The safety program at Conectiv consists of a number of elements, only some of which are required by the RMP rule.   The RMP rule requires the following elements:

1.Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies.

Conectiv implements controls to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous substances. The controls include standard operating procedures, administrative procedures, emergency response plans, inspection programs, detection systems, hazard evaluation programs, training programs, programs to ensure safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of processes within Conectiv.


2. Conectiv Bethlehem and Regulated Substances. 

The Conectiv Bethlehem Power Plant is a power generation facility designed to supply power during peak demand periods. In order to support these operations, Conectiv handles a regulated substance (anhydrous ammonia) in a sufficient quantity covered by the RMP rule, as shown below:

                                                                                                  Maximum             Largest
                                Program       Regulated                               On-site                 Single
Process                      Level          Substance                            Quantity                Vessel 

Anhydrous Ammonia    3           Anhydrous Ammonia               24,000 gals          12,000 gals

(112,000 lbs)        (56,000 lbs)

The plant is designed in two identical power blocks. Each block contains three combustion turbines, three heat recovery steam generators and one steam turbine generator. Each block has its own anhydrous ammonia system to control NOx emissions from the combustion turbines.

3. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps 

The Conectiv Bethlehem Plant focuses on ways to prevent an accidental release of a hazardous substance. The following sub-sections briefly describe the elements of Conectiv's prevention program for utilizing anhydrous ammonia;

   3.1  Process Safety Information: Conectiv maintains a variety of technical documents used to provide safe operation of the covered process. The documents address (1) physical properties of hazardous substances utilized in the process, (2) operating parameters of the equipment/process to include Standard Operating Procedures (SOP), and (3) design basis configuration of process equipment.

   3.2  Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDSs) document the properties of hazardous substances on the premises, including anhydrous ammonia. MSDSs are used to (1) provide health and safety information to employees, contractors and emergency responders; (2) train employees; and (3) perform Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs). MSDSs are used to provide instructions for proper handling of hazardous chemicals at the plant. 

   3.3  Process Hazard Analysis (PHA): The Conectiv Bethlehem Plant performs and periodically updates PHAs for the covered process to identify potential process hazards and generate recommendations to improve the safe operation of the process. A team composed of personnel with engineering, environmental, process operating experience, maintenance, safety and a leader with process hazard analysis experience is assembled to analyze the hazards of the process. Conectiv pr

imarily uses the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) technique, supplemented with checklists to perform this analysis. The PHA team prepares a written report describing the results of the analysis, including a list of recommendations. Responsibility to resolve the recommendations is assigned to plant personnel and, when appropriate, changes to enhance the safety of the process are implemented.                                                                                                                                                                        
   3.4   Operating Procedures: Conectiv Managers, Engineers, Lead Maintenance Operators, Instrumentation and Electronic Technicians, and Operation and Maintenance Technicians work together to develop and maintain operating procedures to define safe methods for performing tasks relating to the process. Conectiv personnel develop and maintain operating procedures to cover all phases of operations including; initial start-up, normal operations, normal shutdown, emergency shutdown, start-up following a turnaround and temporary operations. The Operating Procedures are used both as instructional guides for operating the covered processes and as training tools for both new and experienced operators. The Operating Procedures are updated at least annually to ensure they reflect current operating conditions.                                  .                                                                                     
3.5  Training:  Workers are trained to perform their assigned tasks safely and effectively. The Conectiv training program includes both initial and refresher training that covers: (1) a general overview of the process, (2) the properties and hazards of the substances in the process and (3) a detailed review of the process operating procedures and safe work practices. Oral review and on-the-job training are used to verify the employee understands the process operation prior to job assignment. The operators

are consulted periodically to evaluate the effectiveness and requirement for additional training. Recommendations from the operators are reviewed, and changes are implemented as appropriate.
                                                                                                                                                                                             3.6   Mechanical Integrity:  Conectiv maintains the mechanical integrity of process equipment to prevent equipment failures that could endanger employees and contractors, the public and the environment. This is accomplished by: (1) an inspection and testing program to identify equipment deterioration and damage before the equipment fails, (2) a management of change program to ensure that new and replacement equipment are designed to meet the standards required for service in the covered process and (3) utilize personnel who are specially trained to maintain the process equipment.
                                                                                                                                                                                             3.7   Management of Change:  The Conectiv management of change program evaluates and approves all proposed changes to chemicals, equipment and procedures to ensure changes do not negatively affect safe operations. Changes must be reviewed prior to implementation to ensure that; (1) inadvertent consequences of process changes are prevented, (2) safety consequences of changes are addressed, (3) affected process safety information and operating procedures are updated and (4) the affected employees are notified of the changes.
                                                                                                                                                                                             3.8   Pre-Startup Review:  Conectiv performs a safety review of a new or modified process before the process is placed into s

ervice to ensure that the process is safe to operate. This review confirms that an employee has completed the appropriate training. The review also confirms that adequate safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place and ensure construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications. A pre-startup review checklist is completed to document the review and to ensure that appropriate issues have been addressed.
                                                                                                                                                                                             3.9   Compliance Audit:  Conectiv audits the covered process to evaluate whether the Conectiv prevention program is effectively addressing the safety issues. Conectiv assembles an audit team including personnel knowledgeable in the RMP rule and the process to evaluate whether the prevention program (1) satisfies the requirements of the RMP rule and (2) whether it is sufficient to ensure safe operation of the process. The results of the audits are documented, recommendations are resolved and appropriate improvements to the prevention program are implemented.
                                                                                                                                                                                             3.10  Incident Investigation:  Conectiv investigates all incidents that result in, or could reasonably result in a serious injury to employees and contractors, the public and the environment to prevent similar incidents from recurring. Conectiv trains employees to identify and report any incident requiring investigation. An investigation team is assembled, and the investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident. The results of the incident are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate process improvements are implemented.

3.11  Employee Participation:  The Conectiv Bethlehem employee participation program provides a means to allow workers to participate in the development and continuous improvement of these prevention program elements. Employees are consulted on and informed about various aspects of the prevention program through the training program. Topics include the PHAs and operating procedures as well as access to any support information for the covered processes.
                                                                                                                                                                                             3.12  Hot Work Permits:  Conectiv uses a Hot Work Permit Program to control spark or flame producing activities that could result in fires or explosions at the Bethlehem plant. Conective created a Hot Work Permit form to comply with the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.252(a). Personnel performing hot work are required to have an approved permit prior to beginning their work. 
                                                                                                                                                                                             3.13  Contractors:  Conectiv has established Contractor Safety and Health Guidelines to outline expectations relating to contractor performed work at the Conectiv Bethlehem Plant including work on the covered process. The program reviews the safety record of all contractors to ensure Conectiv only hires contractors who can safely perform the desired job tasks. Conectiv personnel explain to contract supervisor(s); (1) the hazards of the process on which they and their employees will work, (2) Conectiv safe work practices and (3) Conectiv emergency response procedures. Conectiv requires the contractor supervisor(s) to also train each of their emplo

yees prior to beginning their work on a covered process. Conectiv periodically reviews contractor's training documents and work performance to ensure safe work practices are followed.  

4.  Chemical Specific Prevention Steps 
                                                                                                                                                                                          In addition to the required prevention program elements, Conectiv has implemented safety features specific to anhydrous ammonia. Conectiv compared anhydrous and aqueous ammonia and determined anhydrous ammonia was more appropriate for minimizing the potential of serious incident or off-site impact due to the following:
* Decrease in the number of deliveries to the site; therefore less truck traffic,
* Decrease in the number of delivery truck hook-ups and disconnects which is when the majority of all ammonia releases occur.
* Decrease in the number of failure points (i.e., valves, pumps, flanges, etc.) and
* Decrease in the likelihood of corrosion to the operating system due to the nature of anhydrous ammonia
  
The covered process is located almost entirely within the containment area, which further reduces the hazard. The storage tanks are engineered specifically for the anhydrous ammonia system. The underground piping is: (1) double-contained, (2) wrapped with corrosion protection tape, (3) cathodically protected and (4) the interstitial space is charged with nitrogen and monitored.  The process uses a control system with emergency shutdowns to ensure safe operation. Detectors and alarms located around each tank, injection skids and Heat Recovery System Generators (HRSG) provide continuous monitoring for ammonia in the event of a release, providing early detection and aid in quick response if a release incident was to occur.

5. Five-Year Accident History  

Conectiv Bethlehem is required to complete a review of the covered process for incidents occurring in the five-year period prior to the submittal date for the regulation. Since the system's inception there have been no incidents involving the regulated processes resulting in the release of anhydrous ammonia causing on-site or off-site impacts. 

6. Emergency Response Programs  
                                                                                                                                                                                          Conectiv Bethlehem has a written emergency response program to safely respond to accidental releases of hazardous substances. Conectiv does not have "First Responder" capabilities. Conectiv's response will be to notify the City of Bethlehem, the Northampton County LEPC and other off-site emergency response personnel in the event of a potential for serious incident or off-site impact. The Conectiv Emergency Response Plan includes procedures for:
* Informing the LEPC about accidental releases that could reasonably result in offsite consequences,
* Clear identification and communication, roles and responsibilities during an emergency event, and
* Reviewing and updating the Emergency Response Plan  

All Conectiv personnel are trained in 'shelter-in-place' procedures and evacuation procedures. Conectiv periodically coordinates emergency response drills. The written Emergency Response Plan complies with other federal contingency plan regulations (i.e., OPA-90 Regulations, OSHA Regulations 29 CFR 1910.38(a) and 29 CFR 1910.120(a), State EPCRA Rules and Laws) and has been communicated to local emergency response officials and local fire departments. Conectiv maintains an on-going dialogue with the local fire officials and provides additional response information as appropriate.

7. Planned Changes To Improve Safety  

    The Conectiv Bethlehem Plant constantly strives to improve the safety of the regulated process by: (1) following recommended safe practices, (2) soliciting safety suggestions from employees, (3) conducting hazard analysis studies and (4) researching and investigating process incidents from similar operating facilities.
